description: From Middle English faith (also fay), borrowed from Old French fei, feid, from Latin fidem. Displaced native Old English ġelēafa, which was also the word for "belief."

Old French had [θ] as a final devoiced allophone of /ð/ from lenited Latin /d/; this eventually fell silent in the 12th century.  The -th of the Middle English forms is most straightforwardly accounted for as a direct borrowing of a French [θ]. However, it has also been seen as arising from alteration of a French form with -d under influence of English abstract nouns in the suffix -th (e.g. truth, ruth, health, etc.), or as a recharacterisation of a French form like fay, fey, fei with the same suffix, thus making the word equivalent to fay +‎ -th.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Alternative form of in faith (“really, truly”)
examples: 'Faith, friend,' he says, 'that was a nasty fall for a fellow that has supped weel. Where might your road be gaun to?'

entries.meaning: A trust or confidence in the intentions or abilities of a person, object, or ideal from prior empirical evidence.
examples: The faithfulness of Old Faithful gives us faith in it.
I have faith in the goodness of my fellow man.
You need to have faith in yourself, that you can overcome your shortcomings and become a good person.

entries.meaning: A conviction about abstractions, ideas, or beliefs, without empirical evidence, experience, or observation.
examples: I have faith that my prayers will be answered.
I have faith in the healing power of crystals.

entries.meaning: A religious or spiritual belief system.
examples: We seek justice for the Indo-European Folk Faith; what's wrong in our literature for that?

entries.meaning: An obligation of loyalty or fidelity and the observance of such an obligation.
examples: He acted in good faith to restore broken diplomatic ties after defeating the incumbent.
the faith of the foregoing  […]  narrative
